description.narrative: In Jonglei State, South Sudan: about 40,000 persons (about 6,645 households), which is 28% of the population of 145,454 persons (24,492 households)

In South-Sudan, this Reconstruction programme will focus on the following outcomes:
1. Increased level of implementation of local peace agreements, decreased dowry levels and increased mutual respect and cooperation (including cross-border cooperation) in various projects among the tribes and clans living in the targeted areas of Gambella and Jonglei, with special attention for the role of women and of youth.
2. Inclusive improved food security through increased availability and optimal and collaborative use of available livelihood resources and increased services among the various tribes and clans living in the targeted areas of Gambella and Jonglei with special attention for the role of women and of youth.
In this programme ZOA will contribute to enhance stability and security as preconditions for people to rebuild their lives and strengthen their livelihood strategies.

participating-org.narrative: In South Sudan the ZOA partners will involve: • County and payam administration and councils • Traditional elders and traditional structures for peace/settlement negotiations • Youth and Women representatives • Churches (more than 80% of population in the area belongs to a protestant denomination). • Partner NGOs as mentioned above.

activity-date.narrative: The project received initial approval by the ministry of Foreign Affairs on 28th June 2012 for a total amount of 64% of the proposed budget at the time of submission in March 2012. ZOA was then asked to submit a revised project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry decided on the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started further implementation of the project. ZOA found it best to not start the revised project immediately after submission in September 2012 so not to run the risk of beginning project work on a wrong footing, we considered the operational risks of starting the project without having received the donor’s ultimate directions, too high. Therefore, we could only start full project preparations in second half of November and were left with six weeks in 2012 to this effect. The extent of project activity in 2012 has been limited; work has focused on project preparations mainly. (Actual operations took off in 2013.)

policy-marker.narrative: This ZOA programme will contribute to a diminishing of instability and will contribute to human security by addressing the factors which sustain the conflicts and which can be influenced positively.

description.narrative: (South Sudan only) Increased access to reproductive health services and eye-care and attention for inclusion of handicapped people mainstreamed.
25 Government health care workers trained in sexual and reproductive health and eye care by the end of 2015.

comment.narrative: N/A
20 staff (10 Government healthcare workers and 10 health promoters and traditional birth attendants (TBAs)). Cause of deviation: Funding could only allow training of 20 staffs
8 staff were trained on STI and 10 TBAs on handling pregnant women
Activities by PHCCs planned for Pibor could not be implemented due to continuous insecurity and have been shifted to 2014.
No activities in 2016. Progress on indicator already concluded by 2015

description.narrative: At least 120 cataract or trachoma operations done by end of 2015 with 70% of operations classified as good visual acuity after 2 days.

comment.narrative: N/A

124(M=51; F = 73) operated for cataract; 150 (M= 49 , F = 101) surgically repaired for trachoma (target exceeded by 3%). No data on number of clients with visual acuity within 2 days. CMA did not provide info. To be traced in 2016
276 operations done on cataract or Trachoma. No data on clasification, but follow up was carried out by partner

description.narrative: By the end of the project an increase by 20% of PHCCs providing health services in sexual and reproductive health and eye care as part of the governments basic health package.

comment.narrative: No clear baseline info available due to insecurity at time of baseline study.
Activities by PHCCs planned for Pibor could not be implemented due to continuous insecurity and have been shifted to 2014.
No activities in 2016. Progress on indicator already concluded by 2015
Only 1 facility operational in 2014

Targeted 2 out of 2 PHCCs (Pibor and Lekuangole) providing health services in sexual and reproductive health and eye care as part of the governments basic health package in early 2015. No change. No new PHCCs offering STI or Eye care services

description.narrative: Improved capacity for enhanced household productivity in agriculture (Ethiopia and South Sudan)
By the end of the project, average crop production of beneficiary households in target communities has increased by 10% over baseline.

comment.narrative: Baseline: Sorghum production: 132 kilo/HH, maize production: 162 kilo/HH, millet production: 182 kilo/HH.
10% increase when compared to baseline

Akobo: average sorghum production increased (by 12%) to 145kg from 130kg at baseline. Maize decreased 25% from 160kg to 120kg. No data for millet. Pibor: average maize production increased (by 20%) to 195kg from 160 kg at baseline. Sorghum decreased 30% from 130kg to 90 kg and millet decreased 9% from 180kg to 165kg Cause of fall back: Low rainfall and extended dry spells failed crops
10% increase when compared to baseline

Average sorghum production 150 kgs. Maize harvest failed. Pumpkin harvest reasonable to good (observation). Overall production far below baseline data as the result of the failed Maize harvest. Maize is a risky crop in terms of drought resistance and should be re-assessed in onwards programming with the farmers.
10% increase when compared to baseline
In both Akobo and Pibor, no crop production measurements were conducted due to insecurity that affected both farming and project activities for most of 2016 No info on 2016 achievements
10% increase when compared to baseline

Will be verified using household survey at the mid-term-review, planned in 2014. NHDF is indicating a 5% increase of crop production, but we have not been able to verify this because of insecurity in Akobo.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, at least 25% of beneficiary households engaged in agriculture in target communities have added one crop to their portfolio (households having improved access to land) or have added at least one seed variety (households having limited access to land) over the baseline.

comment.narrative: N/A
25% of beneficiaries have added one crop/seed variety to portfolio in comparison to baseline
20% of beneficiaries (66 of 333 households) have diversified their crop production, with sorghum, maize and vegetables (3 crops) added to their crop portfolio.
25% of beneficiaries have added one crop/seed variety to portfolio in comparison to baseline
Akobo: no data on new crops (not available at time of report) Pibor: 36% with new crop (okra); 27% added pumpkins to the portfolio of crops locally grown.
25% of beneficiaries have added one crop/seed variety to portfolio in comparison to baseline

In Akobo: The mix of multiple interventions by various agro-focused agencies in the area of Akobo made direct attribution of farmer activities to only HRESSB not practical. In Pibor: No info due to insecurity in the area and scanty agro-based project activities Progress indicator not assessed
25% of beneficiaries have added one crop/seed variety to portfolio in comparison to baseline
New variety of Sorghum introduced but unsuccesful (damage from birds). New vegetables introduced for dry season agriculture

description.narrative: Improved capacity of relevant local tribal and clan leaders, churches, other organizations and local government to prevent and mitigate conflict and sustain peace and to address underlying cultural contributors to instability and conflict.
By the end of the project, youth are actively included in at least 40% of inter-group conflict resolution efforts in the targeted counties/woredas

comment.narrative: During the baseline survey the youth in SDN were not involved in inter-group conflict resolution efforts/ peace agreements.
Akobo: 100% youth involvement in inter-group conflict resolutions. Pibor: 100% youth involvement: 'no peace deal holds with involving the youth'
In Akobo: 100% youth involvement in inter-group conflict resolutions In Pibor: constant insecurity and instability in the area did not favour project activities in 2016.
Same as in 2013: Youth actively included in 100% of inter-group conflict resolutions efforts for 2014 in Akobo County. In Pibor County only in Likwangole youth were included (no exact data however)

Youth actively included in 100% of inter-group conflict resolutions efforts for 2013 in Akobo County: sports events, monthly peace meetings, micro-projects. No other non ZOA-NHDF peace efforts were organized during this time.

description.narrative: By the end of the project 100 tribal leaders, church leaders, youth group / association leaders, women group / association leaders and local government staff capacitated to lead discussions and organise campaigns for making dowry prices and debts more manageable and adjusting bylaws.

comment.narrative: N/A

In Akobo: 61 people (41 males and 20 females) trained on community-proposed dowry bylaws In Pibor: 1,035 leaders (M = 728 and F = 307) from tribal, church, youth, women and government) were capacitated to lead discussions and organize campaigns for lower dowry prices and adjustment of bylaws by end of 2015.

In Akobo: A general dowry price limit of 25 herds of cattle was adopted and used to arbitrate in cases where parents demanded more for their girls. However, the law does not restrain any person who voluntarily wishes to pay more. In Pibor: no information was gathered on status of this indicator in 2016. Target achieved in Akobo
Meetings were held at all bomas in Akobo East to discuss the new bylaw on lower dowry prices. In Pibor activities will start in 2015.

Two meetings organised to discuss dowry prices and bylaws to manage dowry prices capacitating 120 people. In addition, communities organised matches/ campaigns to create awareness and lobby for dowry reduction.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, functional systems are in place in all targeted counties/Woreda to follow up on local/regional peace agreements.

comment.narrative: N/A: Reference point is one peace committee (in Akobo) at time of baseline study.
County peace committee Akobo East effective supported by Boma peace committees. Interactions with peace committees from outside the county. Pibor County no functional system in 2014

In Akobo: Boma peace committees work with County Peace committees and the latter interact with outside peace committees. In Pibor: county government structures link with traditional leaderships who in turn work with youth leaderships in peace resolutions. Hierarchy from grassroots (youth leaders) to county government is observed. On track

In Akobo: Payam/Boma peace committees formed under HRESB met and solved communal problems. e.g. compensation of victim families, cross-border meetings, community dialogues and making referrals of complicated cases to County authority . In Pibor: Constant insecurity and instability in the area did not favour project activities in 2016. Target partially achieved in Akobo area, but not Pibor in 2016)
One peace committee (Akobo) in place & it has been able to hold 11 follow-up meetings in 2013, plus implement resolutions from these meetings.

description.narrative: By the end of the project 50% of targeted communities have developed initial early warning systems against cattle raiding.

comment.narrative: No formal Early Warning System is in place
75% of targeted payams (3 out of 4) in Akobo County have early warning systems against cattle raids, managed by the payam peace committee.
75% of targeted payams (3 out of 4) in Akobo East County have early warning systems against cattle raids, managed by the payam peace committee. In Pibor County no early warning systems established

Akobo: 4 out of 5 Payams (80%) have functional systems (except Pultuak) Pibor: 4 out of 4 Payams (100%) have a 4-level warning system: ●Indigenous forecast knowledge ●local monitoring mechanism ●community-based alerts ●community response component Average is 90%

In Akobo: Early warning systems functional in 4 out of 5 Payams (exception was Pultuak) as in 2015. In Pibor: No progress info, based on the recurring insecurity and political instability which did not allow for the monitoring of Early Warning Systems. Therefore 80% is the minimum.

description.narrative: Inclusive improved food security through increased availability and optimal and collaborative use of available livelihood resources and increased services among the various tribes and clans living in the targeted areas of Gambella and Jonglei, with special attention for the role of women and of youth.

By the end of the project, access to a safe and reliable source of drinking water has increased by 30% among 37.800 beneficiaries (5.400 households) in target areas of Pibor County; and among 8.000 beneficiaries (1.000 households) in the Woredas of Akobo and Wanthoa.

comment.narrative: Baseline is average number: 43% of the people have access to water through hand pumps and piped water during the rainy season, 39% have access during the dry season (assumption: safe and reliable refers to hand pumps and piped water).
30% increase when compared to baseline
GPAA: Partner just started implementation
30% increase compared to baseline

In Akobo: at least 5,000 people (700 HH) regained access to safe drinking water - at least a 30% achievement as earlier targeted! Target was not realized in Pibor, since no borehole rehab was done and no new boreholes were drilled. Not on track: Inadequate funding for interventions to 'improve access to safe and reliable water' for the estimated beneficiaries. Most activities limited to improving water troughs that improve water access to cattle
30% increase compared to baseline
In both Akobo and Pibor, no assessment was made in 2016, mainly due to the political instability of South Sudan for most of 2016. Indicator target achievement not assessed
30% increase when compared to baseline
Is an outcomeindicator, not output

description.narrative: At least 80% of the 1,000 + 1,000 (Jonglei/Gambella) beneficiary households show improvement in Food Consumption Score with 10 points over the baseline.

comment.narrative: Food Consumption Score
28.5 is average FCS. Akobo: 36.5 Pibor: 20.52 (Not on track: poor harvest due to too inadequate rains in 2015, especially in Pibor)
10 point increase in FCS
Data to be collected in 2015
In both Akobo and Pibor, no assessment of Food Consumption Score was made in 2016, mainly due to the political instability of South Sudan for most of 2016. Indicator target achievement not assessed
10 point increase in FCS
Is an outcome indicator, not output

description.narrative: By end of the project there will be a sustainable system of managing and controlling STIs problems including functional referral avenues established in all government health services facilities in targeted areas of Pibor County, with a catchment area of 44,500 persons and serving 960 clients for STIs and 480 for eye care services (at least 25% of clients being operated on trachoma or cataract).

comment.narrative: N/A

GPAA: Referral system is unrealistic because of access problems of Pibor Area. Health staff at Pibor has been trained on STIs but only 1 health facility was operational in 2014. Treatment on eye diseases more than targeted in 2014
Is an outcome indicator, not output

On track or exceeded. ● # of STI clients = 3,113 (1,124 rapid testing & treatment; 1,989 clinical diagnosis and treatment): target exceeded by 224% ●# of Eye care clients = 1,357(M = 875; F = 512) : target exceeded by 183% ●# of clients operated for trachoma or cataract= 124 (M=51; F = 73); 150 surgically repaired for trachoma (M=49; F=101) : target exceeded by 3%. 10 persons (M=3, F=7)other surgeries i.e. pterygium/granuloma excisions. Not on track: Sustainable system of managing and controlling STIs . No permanent facilities, lack of equipment, inadequate or no supplies and high staff turnover due to inadequate, overdelayed or no staff salaries from government.

Project target at OUTPUT level had already been achieved or exceeded in 2015. No outputs measured in 2016 At OUTCOME level in 2016, no sustainable system of managing and controlling STIs was in place. Output targets were achieved, but OUTCOMES were not realized

By the end of the project, the percentage of households that use water from hand pumps as the primary source of household water consumption has increased by at least 10% In Pibor locality and 30% in Wanthoa and Akobo Woredas.

comment.narrative: 60 % in rainy season, 61% in dry season.
10% (Pibor) - 30% (Wanthoa/Akobo) increase when compared to baseline
GPAA: still to be implemented
10% (Pibor) - 30% (Wanthoa/Akobo) increase when compared to baseline
No activities in 2016. Progress on indicator already concluded by 2015
10% (Pibor) - 30% (Wanthoa/Akobo) increase when compared to baseline
Not achieved. All activities to end of 2015 in both Akobo and Pibor did not address this indicator aspect due to funding constraints.
10% (Pibor) - 30% (Wanthoa/Akobo) increase when compared to baseline
WASH activities planned for Pibor could not be implemented due to continuous insecurity and have been shifted to 2014.

10 trainees on vocational skills and follow up carried out. All are active at Akobo market. 100% of the trainess have income, however at limited levels.
Akobo : 20 out of 30 vocational skills trainees able to earn income (67%). Pibor: 11 out of 11 vocational skills trainees able to earn income (100%) 83% is average percentage.
Akobo: Same as in 2015 (20 out of 30 vocational skills trainees able to earn income) . On track. (67% success)

comment.narrative: Nine boreholes need to be rehabilitated (info via RRC) and a water trough for livestock will be built.
10 out of 27 functional water points modified. (Pibor had 6 modified out of existing 18 and Lekuangole had 4 modified out of existing 9) Target can be reached in 2016
GPAA: WASH activities planned for Pibor could not be implemented due to continuous insecurity and have been shifted to 2015.
No activities in 2016. Progress on indicator already concluded by 2015
WASH activities planned for Pibor could not be implemented due to continuous insecurity and have been shifted to 2014.

description.narrative: Increased level of implementation of local peace agreements, decreased dowry levels and increased mutual respect and cooperation (including cross-border cooperation) in various projects among the tribes and clans living in the targeted areas of Gambella and Jonglei, with special attention for the role of women and of youth.
By the end of the project, bylaws regulating the dowry prices are in place in at least 30% of the targeted payams and are being respected.

comment.narrative: N/A

100% targeted payams have bylaws regulating the dowry prices. Compliance to by-laws not absolute as legally-binding ratification is pending on the Government side. Target partially achieved. (Bylaws established, but not yet legally enforceable)
3 out of 7 payams (42%), compliance to be established in 2015

9 out 9 Payams (4 in Pibor and 5 in Akobo) have tribally-defined bylaws as local legal references. Compliance is not absolute. The parents of the bride still play a key role in decisions. Negotiations on-going with government on documenting binding standards. Agreements done but all drafted Payam bylaws to be documented and legally ratified.
Is an outcome indicator, not output

description.narrative: In the targeted counties/ woredas 70% of the action points flowing from five local/regional peace agreements are actively followed up on, with a focus on active participation of youth.

comment.narrative: N/A
4 out of 7 payams have peace agreements. Also peace agreements with committees outside the targeted counties. Follow up to be established later in 2015

Cumulatively: In Pibor - 8 out of 8 action points flowing from 4 local peace agreements were followed up. In Akobo - 7 out of 10 action points from 5 peace agreements have been followed up with active participation of the youth. Average is 85%

In Akobo: (cumulatively) action points from all 5 out of 5 peace agreements were followed up. Result: Violent conflicts were either prevented or mitigated with active participation of youth and women. In Pibor: (cumulatively) action points from 4 out of 4 peace agreements had been followed up. For most of 2016 due to unstable political climate in Pibor the project was less active. Target achieved
Is an outcome indicator, not output

description.narrative: By the end of the project, at least 30% of the targeted beneficiaries indicates an improvement in their perception of shared identity and shared values with other groups.

comment.narrative: Value is 1.33 on a five points scale.
30% of beneficiaries indicates an improvement in their perception
Exact figure not established in 2014. Indications are positive. Data to be established in 2015
30% of beneficiaries indicates an improvement in their perception
Is an outcome indicator, not output
See Outcome and Output comments for 31st Dec 2015. Target achievement not measured (due to lack of clarity on indicator measurement approach.)

The project did not measure this outcome due to lack of clarity on methodology / approach to the measurement. Proxy indicator: Conflict resolution initiatives with peace committees yielded the peaceful return of at least 50 herds of rustled cattle and exchange of 5 abducted girls and at least 6 women to where they rightfully belonged.

description.narrative: Increased opportunities for positive inter-tribe/clan interaction on livelihood related matters, peace building, dowry reduction, sports.

By the end of the project 11 (5 in Gambella; 6 in Jonglei) projects proposed and being implemented that promote inclusion and mutual respect. These projects must require inter-tribe/clan interaction and can deal with matters such as access to water, grazing land, trust building or campaigns aimed at making dowry prices and/or debts more manageable.

comment.narrative: N/A
3 out of 6 projects in Akobo County, Jonglei State, implemented to promote inclusion and mutual respect.
In Akobo: 3 projects (carpentry, welding and micro-enterprises) In Pibor: 2 projects (carpentry and masonry/block & concrete practice) Deviation of minus 1: funding shortfall contributed to this

In Akobo: HRESSB trained carpenters and welders were self-employed and self-reliant. Micro-enterprise training was not realized. In Pibor: Trained 11 youths in Brick making and carpentry in 2015 but No info if they are employed due to disruptive political developments in the area for most of 2016 Indicator target partially achieved (only 2 out of 6 project expectations were realized)
Trainees for vocational skills were selected from different clans in order to build mutual respect. In total 3 (50%) projects were implemented

description.narrative: By the end of the project 6 (3 in Gambella; 3 in Jonglei) inter-tribe/clan sports competitions held

comment.narrative: N/A
2 out of 3 football tournaments held in Akobo County, Jonglei State, (youth from the 4 payams participated).

In Akobo: 6 football matches from 2013 to 2015. Akobo West - 57 sports members; Akobo East - 76 sports members. Pibor: 6 football competitions: 2 each in Pibor, Lekuangole and Gumuruk Payams; non in Verteth.
In Akobo: sporting competitions by respective Payams were organized. In Pibor: No info provided due to insecurity in the area for most of 2016.
in Akobo East County (including all payams) 1 sports competition was held. Peace messages are part of the very popular event

description.narrative: The project received initial approval by the ministry of Foreign Affairs on 28th June 2012 for a total amount of 64% of the proposed budget at the time of submission in March 2012. ZOA was then asked to submit a revised project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry decided on the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started further implementation of the project. ZOA found it best to not start the revised project immediately after submission in September 2012 so not to run the risk of beginning project work on a wrong footing, we considered the operational risks of starting the project without having received the donor’s ultimate directions, too high. Therefore, we could only start full project preparations in second half of November and were left with six weeks in 2012 to this effect. The extent of project activity in 2012 has been limited; work has focused on project preparations mainly. (Actual operations took off in 2013.) As a result of the 36% budget cut, all outputs in South Sudan were reduced by cuts ranging from over 80% to as little as 10%. For outputs that were reduced minimally this was done because they were considered as central and core activities in peace building. The fishery component of the project had to be cut entirely although it is an important alternative source of livelihood during the rainy season. Related cuts were a boat for fishing and transportation. The governance and overall management development of partner organizations will now be addressed through advise by the Programme Advisor albeit with no project funds available anymore to support this work. The nature of our intervention was not changed.

title.narrative: Not applicable for this annual report: see narrative above
